issue.title: Elaborate on Exposed=* advice

labels.name: clarification
labels.description: Standard could be clearer

issue.body:
Currently we have this:

> `[Exposed=*]` is to be used with care. It is only appropriate when an API does not expose significant new capabilities. If the API might be restricted or disabled in some environments, it is preferred to list the globals explicitly. 

I think it would help if we listed the principles or criteria that were used to select the initial set of interfaces. Ideally specific enough that it's clear why `ErrorEvent` is included and `MouseEvent` and `reportError()` are excluded. As that would help a lot with carrying this forward consistently into the future.

(Context: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/7591.)

cc @Ms2ger @domenic @smaug---- @leobalter @caridy @mhofman

comment.body:
It seems like so far the set of APIs chosen to be included inside shadow realms has been limited to interfaces (rather than to methods or properties defined in the global property) plus `self` which is defined programmatically in #5339. In particular, there doesn't seem to be any reason to exclude methods like `setTimeout`, `reportError` or even `structuredClone`, other than the fact that `[Exposed=*]` as currently defined doesn't work for them.

I don't think such methods have been considered that much, and maybe this is not the right issue (since as mentioned `[Exposed=*]` wouldn't work with methods), but it is something that should not be left out of consideration just because it would be more difficult to make them work in the specification.

issue.title: Consider not exposing ErrorEvent/PromiseRejectionEvent in ShadowRealms
issue.body:
Exposing PromiseRejectionEvent in Shadow Realms doesn't make much sense, since the global isn't an EventTarget.
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#unhandled-promise-rejections just doesn't work with that kind of globals.
And https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#report-the-exception doesn't really work either, again because the global isn't an EventTarget.

comment.body:
> To avoid this complexity, I would recommend that both uncaught errors and unhandled rejections have a mechanism to be handled directly inside the ShadowRealm. That's why I suggested above a new `globalThis.errors` which would be an event target for these purposes.

HTML has a mechanism where if an error is uncaught inside a dedicated worker, [it will be reported as an error in the worker's "parent"](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/workers.html#runtime-script-errors-2), possibly propagating up the chain until you reach a non-dedicated worker agent (which usually is the window's main agent). The thrown exception is obviously not included in such error events (the `error` attribute of `ErrorEvent` is set to `null`), but if something similar is adopted for ShadowRealms, it could include a copied error with the semantics in https://github.com/tc39/proposal-shadowrealm/blob/main/errors.md.

There doesn't seem to be anything equivalent for unhandled promise rejections, but I wonder if it could be added as well.

labels.name: core
labels.description: related to core/ dir

issue.body:
`ops/lib.rs` has the following safety comment:

https://github.com/denoland/deno/blob/226209714168e5b85410db773f06debb7cf34511/ops/lib.rs#L120-L123

But `Deno.core.ops` is user-accessible, and its functions can be called by the user, so this guarantee does not necessarily hold.

pull_request.title: refactor: Have `ArrayBuffer::data` return `Option<NonNull<c_void>>`
pull_request.body:
The pointer returned by `ArrayBuffer::data` might be null if the backing store has zero length, but the return type `*mut c_void` does not force the user to consider this case. This change makes the return type `Option<NonNull<c_void>>`, which is semantically equivalent, but which forces users of the API to handle the `None` case.

This PR is the `ArrayBuffer` counterpart to #817.

This is a breaking API change.

issue.title: Proposal for safe async I/O with `ArrayBuffer`s
Proposal for safe async I/O with `ArrayBuffer`s

comment.body: I just realized that we'd have to figure out how to make this work with the [TC39 resizable buffers proposal](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-resizablearraybuffer), and it might not be trivial. But doing async I/O in repeated non-blocking synchronous steps _can_ work with a resizing buffer, which is much better than borrowing a slice that then might end up covering memory past the end of the `ArrayBuffer` (as it would be in the way Deno does I/O currently).

pull_request.title: experiment(core): Make resource I/O ops take `DetachedBuffer`
pull_request.body:
In Rust, it is UB if a shared slice (of elements without interior mutability) gets mutated while it is borrowed, and it is also UB if a mutable slice gets mutated _or accessed_ while it is borrowed except through the borrow. In async ops in particular, it is unsound to deref (mutably or immutably) a `ZeroCopyBuf` across an `await` point, since there might be references to the `ArrayBuffer` which are accessible to JS, and therefore the slice could be mutated while it is borrowed in our async op.

`Deno.core.{read,write,writeAll}`, which are the backbone of streams and other I/O APIs in Deno, have this issue; and fixing them would greatly reduce the surface for this unsoundness, and would make a first step towards a more in-depth fix of this issue.

The way this PR fixes these APIs is by changing their `ZeroCopyBuf` input parameters to `DetachedBuffer` –which makes the `ArrayBuffer`'s backing store inaccessible from JS– and returning the same `DetachedBuffer` in cases where it is needed.

This API can be used straightforwardly to implement web streams, but there still are `Reader` and `Writer` interfaces in `Deno.Conn`, `Deno.FsFile` and `Deno.std{in,out,err}` which expect a passed buffer to be read or written to asynchronously. In order to make these APIs work with an underlying API based on `DetachedBuffer`, the contents are being copied. Since all of these APIs have a stream-based version, hopefully the old APIs can be deprecated, making this decrease in performance less relevant for the overall experience of Deno users.

comment.body:
> Can you provide any context on performance changes with this PR?

I haven't run any benchmarks yet, but I expect that changing the `read` and `write` methods of those APIs to make a copy would degrade their performance to some extent. I'll try to find any benchmarks that use these methods, or write some if there aren't any, later today.

issue.title: Disallow memory slices as inputs to async ops
issue.body:
In Rust, it is UB if a slice is mutated while borrowed except through the slice itself, and it is also UB if a mutable slice is read while borrowed. The op macro allows borrowing an `ArrayBuffer{,View}` as a memory slice for the duration of an op, but this is not sound for async ops, since the `ArrayBuffer` could be accessed from JS during the await points. This PR therefore disallows such automatic borrowing only for async ops.

pull_request.title: Add `ArrayBuffer::set_detach_key`
pull_request.body: This method, introduced in V8 10.9, makes it so an `ArrayBuffer` object is impossible to detach unless a specific detach key is passed to the `detach` method. Such `ArrayBuffer`s still count as detachable as per the `ArrayBuffer::is_detachable` method, but otherwise behave much like WebAssembly memories.

commits.message:
Ignore environment variables set by cargo (#825)

This avoids constant rebuilds when alternating between running

$ cargo build
$ cargo run <something that runs cargo build>

Since the second command will see these environment variables set
during the logic deciding if build.rs should be rerun or not.

Since these are cargo specific variables, hopefully cargo already does
the right thing without our help.

Rolling to V8 9.7.106.2 (#827)

Co-authored-by: Luca Casonato <hello@lcas.dev>

Make lifetime in `FunctionCallback` signature more restrictive (#822)

This makes the callbacks themselves less restrictive. A test is added
the would fail to compile before.

chore: Specify the rust toolchain version (#821)

Tests in tests/compile_fail/ depend on a specific toolchain version. For
example, they currently fail with 1.58.0-nightly because of extra
warnings.

refactor: Have `BackingStore::data` return `Option<NonNull<c_void>>` (#817)

The pointer returned by `BackingStore::data` might be null if the
backing store has zero length, but the return type `*mut c_void` does
not force the user to consider this case. This change makes the return
type `Option<NonNull<c_void>>`, which is semantically equivalent, but
which forces users of the API to handle the `None` case.

This is a breaking API change.

v8: fix segfault during concurrent isolate creation/disposal on Windows (#829)

This patch includes a test for this issue.

The V8 patch is intentionally left simple to avoid merge conflicts in
the future. To be landed upstream, the `unwindinfo_use_count_` would
probably have to be made non-atomic and we'd have to add a cctest.

Upstream bug: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/v8/issues/detail?id=12393

Fixes: #714

pull_request.title: Update `ArrayBuffer::was_detached` to not use `OpenHandle`
pull_request.body: In #1103, the `ArrayBuffer::was_detached` method was added to rusty_v8 to fill a gap in the C++ API, and it was implemented using the internal `v8::Utils::OpenHandle`. Since then, a `WasDetached` method was added to `ArrayBuffer` in V8 10.9. This PR updates the implementation to use that.

issue.title: Atomics.waitAsync bug

comment.body:
> Wanted to see if I can help find the bug, but I can't even find the place where `Atomics.waitAsync` is implemented.

Deno doesn't implement `Atomics.waitAsync`, that's implemented in V8, the JS engine that Deno (as well as Node.js and Chrome) use. Assuming this is not a V8 bug, it's almost certainly related to Deno's event loop code not knowing about `Atomics.waitAsync` and only knowing about "ops" (Deno's word for Rust functions that are passed into deno_core so they get exposed into the Javascript VM). The relevant code is in [`JsRuntime::poll_event_loop`](https://github.com/denoland/deno/blob/main/core/runtime.rs#LL1019) (or perhaps elsewhere in `JsRuntime`), but I doubt it would be easy to fix.

comment.body:
It used to be the case that passing SABs to Rust didn't work, because `ZeroCopyBuf` explicitly disallowed SABs. #15922 made this possible, and apparently no one noticed.

Accessing SAB data as a `&[u8]` or `&mut [u8]` is unsound because the buffer could be modified at any point by a worker. It has essentially the same safety guarantees as transmuting a `&[AtomicU8]`.

issue.title: Web Compatibility

labels.name: compat-bug-proposal
labels.description: Proposals for web compat bugs

labels.name: focus-area-proposal
labels.description: Focus Area Proposal

issue.body:
### Description

A focus area for small bugs that cause known site compatibility issues, or documented problems for authors creating libraries or sites, but which are not part of a larger feature that's appropriate for its own focus area.

### Rationale

Observed compatibility bugs which cause breakage for users are often not missing features, but specific cases where existing browsers don't follow the spec for features that are implemented. On their own these would be hard to fit into the Interop process since a focus area for a single bug, however important, is hard to weigh as part of the metric. However having a single focus area for these issues seems to have worked well in 2022, with browsers going from ~20% to ~100%, and fixing several bugs that were known to cause problems for users, but had not previously got priority.

### Specification

All included bugs will have a specification (although in some cases it may be that "success" is changing the specification, testcase, and "conforming" implementations to match what's actually required by compat).

Inclusions will be motivated by observed compat issues (e.g. in [webcompat.com](https://webcompat.com) or author-reported issues that they've had to work around when developing libraries.

### Tests

Since this is a somewhat miscellaneous selection of bugs, it's anticipated that tests may be added from other focus areas where the overall focus area doesn't get priority but there are a small number of observed pain points which do get priority. During the selection process participants can request removal of any tests that would cause them to object to the proposal.

Suggested bugs / rationale (tests to be added):

* Remove (or standardise?) overflow: overlay
  * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=55436
  * https://github.com/webcompat/knowledge-base/blob/main/data/overflow-overlay.yml
* Flexbox/abspos paint order
  * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=606208
* Decorating box semantics
  * Webcompat issue: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1584348
  * https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=135353
  * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1008951 (recently fixed)

comment.body:
>    * white-space: break-spaces
>      * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1261435
>      * https://codepen.io/kizu/pen/mdMEOvw can be converted to a reftest with some care

In Igalia we're starting to look into this issue, and we'll probably be fixing it at some point in 2023. The issue should probably be limited to the fact that Chromium counts an element boundary before a space as a line breaking opportunity, and you can reproduce this in a test case that doesn't use zoom. The fact that different zoom levels result in different line breaks even when the line width does not depend on the viewport size is a separate issue that should not count for Interop 2023.

However, as we were initially looking into this bug, we noticed that Webkit does seem to have this bug in some cases, although maybe not in all of the cases where Chromium has it. So should it still count for Interop 2023?

issue.title: Add Blob and File
issue.body: Closes: https://github.com/wintercg/proposal-common-minimum-api/issues/17

comment.body: The File API spec hasn't been well maintained for some time, and there are a couple long-standing issues where the spec is known to be broken (such as w3c/FileAPI#43). However, since `FormData` requires `Blob` and `File`, and there's no other way to have files in `multipart/form-data` (short of actually implementing the serialization or parsing manually), I guess adding them would be fine.

issue.title: structuredClone(): fix WPT cases to test transferables with the { transfer: [ list of transferables ] } second parameter
issue.body:
In the `structuredClone` algorithm, the second parameter passed should be
```js
{
  transfer: [ obj1, obj2 ] // list of transferables
}
```
rather than just an array.

This behavior is specified in <https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-structuredclone> and implemented by Chrome, Firefox, and Node.js.

comment.body:
`runner.structuredClone` is a testing API implemented by runners defined elsewhere. For example, `html/webappapis/structured-clone/structured-clone.any.js` takes the second argument of `runner.structuredClone` and passes it as the `transfer` property of the object in the second parameter – whereas `html/infrastructure/safe-passing-of-structured-data/window-postmessage.window.js` simply passes the second argument of `runner.structuredClone` as the second argument of `window.postMessage`, since that is allowed. So this PR is not needed, and it would actually break things unless the runners are updated in turn.

If there is some runner that's using this second argument without mapping it, that should be changed, but probably in a separate PR.

issue.title: The `anchor()` function doesn't support variables as anchor targets
issue.body:
The optional first argument of the `anchor()` function, which is a dashed ident that indicates the anchor target, can be replaced by a custom property: for example, `anchor(var(--anchor) left)`. This variable substitution is not supported in this polyfill.

https://codepen.io/andreubotella/pen/mdKexxX

This polyfill doesn't set any additional styles on the target element, and therefore it shows up below the anchor. Whereas on (canary) Chromium with the `CSSAnchorPosition` feature enabled, it is positioned just right of the "Anchor" text.

Supporting this, together with #44, will allow defining a reusable class for tooltips in a CSS file and allow individual elements to define their anchor names or the anchor to be positioned against using `style` attributes, since this is arguably semantic CSS.

The codepen in the OP currently throws an exception that will be fixed with #47, but even with that fix applied, it still does not apply any `left` or `top` styles to `.target`. In fact, the `parseAnchorFn` function in parse.ts only accepts identifier tokens as the anchor name.

```

**Describe the solution you'd like**

https://deno.land/manual@v1.25.3/jsx_dom/linkedom

comment.body:
> Could you provide some context on `ShadowRealm`? Is there an issue / PR about this?

It's a JS API proposal that's currently being worked on: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-shadowrealm

Unlike most new JS APIs that Deno implements automatically because they ship in V8, this one requires some work to support in the internals of Deno. You can follow the work at denoland/deno#13239 (although the work recently had to be rolled back in denoland/deno#16366 because it was blocking certain refactors; it should hopefully be relanded in a couple weeks).

However, `vm` needs some more support in `deno_core` (and maybe `deno_runtime`) than `ShadowRealm` needs, because you cannot cross objects across the realm boundary with `ShadowRealm` but you can with `vm`. This would need a lot of checking that everything is handled correctly, and that certain realm interactions happen properly, that wouldn't be needed with `ShadowRealm`.

issue.title: Clarify value direction for elements "progress" and "meter" with vertical writing mode

labels.name: i18n-tracker
labels.description: Group bringing to attention of Internationalization, or tracked by i18n but not needing response.

labels.name: i18n-jlreq
labels.description: Notifies Japanese script experts of relevant issues

labels.name: i18n-clreq
labels.description: Notifies Chinese script experts of relevant issues

labels.name: i18n-mlreq
labels.description: Notifies traditional Mongolian script experts of relevant issues

issue.body:
Currently, elements "progress" and "meter" don't have well defined behavior when they have the style `writing-mode: vertical-lr` or `writing-mode: vertical-rl`. For example, Firefox is the only vendor to support vertical writing-mode for these elements. Here is what a progress bar looks like: ```HTML 70% ``` Question 1: Should the value part (blue color) of the element be rendered from top down (as reading is normally done from top to bottom) or should it be rendered bottom to top (so it looks like a glassware that gets filled up)?

Further, currently for the horizontal mode, we are able to change the direction of the progress bar from left-to-right to right-to-left. ```HTML 70% 70% ``` However, there are no direction for ttb `top-to-bottom` or btt `bottom-to-top` (not that I am aware of at least). Question 2: Should there be a way to allow changing direction for the vertical writing modes?


Spec link: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-progress-element https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-meter-element https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes-4/#block-flow https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes/#direction (ps: was told that this question is better fit for whatwg/html instead of csswg https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7929)

comment.body:
> I'm curious to know why you think this is not good practice (especially given that Blink, Gecko, and WebKit browsers all currently apply the RTL directionality for the progress bar). Do you have information from RTL script users indicating a preference for it to be otherwise?

It looked like the OP was about changing the direction of progress/meter bars in absence of any internationalization need for it, just as a styling change. That's what I was objecting to. If that's not what was meant, my bad.

issue.title: Clarify value direction for elements "progress" and "meter" with vertical writing mode
issue.body:
Currently, elements "progress" and "meter" don't have well defined behavior when they have the style `writing-mode: vertical-lr` or `writing-mode: vertical-rl`. For example, Firefox is the only vendor to support vertical writing-mode for these elements. Here is what a progress bar looks like: ```HTML 70% ``` Question 1: Should the value part (blue color) of the element be rendered from top down (as reading is normally done from top to bottom) or should it be rendered bottom to top (so it looks like a glassware that gets filled up)?

Further, currently for the horizontal mode, we are able to change the direction of the progress bar from left-to-right to right-to-left. ```HTML 70% 70% ``` However, there are no direction for ttb `top-to-bottom` or btt `bottom-to-top` (not that I am aware of at least). Question 2: Should there be a way to allow changing direction for the vertical writing modes?


Spec link: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-progress-element https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-meter-element https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes-4/#block-flow https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes/#direction (ps: was told that this question is better fit for whatwg/html instead of csswg https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7929)

comment.body:
The `direction` CSS property isn't meant to change the direction of a progress bar, but to change the direction of the inline progression of text, meant to be used for languages that are written right-to-left such as Hebrew and Arabic. Changing the direction of the progress bar is a side effect. And in cases such as writing rotated RTL languages in vertical text, the `direction` property can still be used ([where "left" maps to top and "right" to bottom](https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-writing-modes/#line-left)).

That said, HTML should indeed probably specify the native (and primitive) apparence of `<progress>` and `<meter>` in terms of [`block-size` and `inline-size`](https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-logical-1/#propdef-block-size), rather than `height` and `width`.

Update `from_raw_with_void_ptr` to support types other than `Box`

This PR updates the `from_raw_with_void_ptr` lint, which covered
`Box::from_raw`, to also cover the `from_raw` static method of the
`Rc`, `Arc`, `alloc::rc::Weak` and `alloc::sync::Weak` types.

It also improves the description and error messages of this lint.

---

changelog: [`from_raw_with_void_ptr`]: Now works with the `Rc`, `Arc`, `alloc::rc::Weak` and `alloc::sync::Weak` types.

Generate lint categories and explanations with `declare_clippy_lint`

Changes it to be a proc_macro rather than macro_rules

Auto merge of #9541 - Alexendoo:declare-proc-macro, r=flip1995

Generate lint categories and explanations with `declare_clippy_lint`

This means contributors will no longer have to run `cargo dev update_lints` after changing a lints documentation or its category, which may also mean fewer merge conflicts in general

It works by swapping `declare_clippy_lint` out for a `proc_macro` of the same name. The proc macro emits a `LintInfo` alongside the generated `Lint` which are gathered into `declared_lint::LINTS`. The categories/explanations are then read from `declared_lint::LINTS` at runtime

The removal of `src/docs` is split into a separate commit to be more easily ignored

It is slightly slower though, adding a bit under a second to build time. Less noticeable in full builds or with a slower linker (benchmark uses mold)

```bash
hyperfine --warmup 2 \
    --parameter-list commit "declare-proc-macro,master" \
    --command-name "{commit}" \
    --setup "git checkout {commit}" \
    --prepare "touch clippy_lints/src/lib.rs" \
    "cargo build"
```
```
Benchmark 1: declare-proc-macro
  Time (mean ± σ):     10.731 s ±  0.154 s    [User: 7.739 s, System: 1.791 s]
  Range (min … max):   10.598 s … 11.125 s    10 runs

Benchmark 2: master
  Time (mean ± σ):      9.422 s ±  0.094 s    [User: 7.183 s, System: 1.732 s]
  Range (min … max):    9.287 s …  9.624 s    10 runs

Summary
  'master' ran
    1.14 ± 0.02 times faster than 'declare-proc-macro'
```

cc `@llogiq` for `--explain`

issue.title: "Abort a running script" doesn't abort function invocations

comment.body:
> Right now [ECMA-262 doesn’t really allow for this to occur](https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/issues/401). Like, it’s not just missing from ES, it’s “impossible” as a consequence of ES’s own semantics I think(?) This seems to be why the section opens with “Although the JavaScript specification does not account for this possibility.” There are more related issues linked to from that one which color in the picture more.
> 
> The changes needed are nuts and bolts things squarely inside the ES “jurisdiction,” e.g. it’d touch the real scary stuff (well, to me I mean) related to memory model invariants I suspect & till ES’s own semantics permit termination to occur, it seems short & sweet on the HTML side is probably a safer stopgap than attempted precision that’s known to be wrong underneath.

True, but the UA-level (rather than JS engine-level) semantics, in terms of what happens when script execution is aborted during a callback invocation, are not defined at all, and this would indeed fall on the HTML / WebIDL side to define. I suppose this can't be done fully until TC39 specifies aborting scripts, but some progress in defining the semantics could still be made before that.

commits.message: Add more non-normative text in the SET spec

Merge pull request #7800 from vmpstr/update-set-intro

[css-shared-element-transitions-1] Add more non-normative text in the SET spec

Merge pull request #7818 from zhangenming/patch-2

[css-contain-2] fix a/an typo.

[css-fonts-4] Give clearer advice to authors about font-feature-settings and font-variation-settings (#7815)

This patch does a few things:
1. Fixes a small handful of whitespace / typo problems
2. Adds an example showing how the font-weight descriptor can accept a range
3. Advises authors to use high-level font-variant properties instead of font-feature-settings
4. Rewrites an example to follow the above advice
5. Advises authors to use high-level font properties instead of font-variation-settings

[resize-observer] Tweak naming to include "resize" on algorithm / etc names.

As per suggestion in https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8348.
[css-grid-1][css-grid-2] Slight editorial tweak to make the 'grid' options clearer.
[css-grid-1][css-grid-2] Clarify that <'grid-template'> serialization is preferred if 'grid' is ambiguous. #7805
[css-grid-2] Generate separate hypoth items for each edge, so assymmetric mbp is handled correctly. #7465
[css-grid-1][css-grid-2][editorial] Clarify that tracks can't be *fully* intrinsic, but can have an intrinsic length (if paired with a fixed in minmax()). #7238

Removed mentioning of orphans and widows

The `orphans` and `widows` properties were moved to CSS Fragmentation 3. Therefore they got removed.
[css-color-4] Missing in rgb serializes as 0,  fix #6959
Specify that highlight repaints must be async (#6987)

[css-pseudo] text decorations on highlight pseudos (closes #6022) (#6666)

Clarify highlight decoration semantics

[css-2022] Set up 2022 snapshot

Includes 'hyphenate-character' as a shippable property, as per #6887
Fix to create symlinks inside the /test folder

Generate timestamps.json file w/ git timestamps for sources

For the GH Pages deployment, this change generates a timestamps.json file
that maps each shortname in the repo to a timestamp representing the time
for the most recent commit of corresponding Bikeshed source file for that
shortname — enabling any downstream users/consumers of the deployed
GH Pages specs to have accurate last-committed data for all sources.

This commit is a port of w3c/csswg-drafts#7898.

Co-authored-by: Michael[tm] Smith <mike@w3.org>

Do full clone rather than shallow clone

This change causes the GH Pages build to do a full clone rather than a
shallow clone. This is necessary in order to get the correct timestamps
for all sources (see 8a88ad6).

Otherwise, without this change, git doesn’t report accurate timestamps
for any sources; instead it reports the same timestamp for all of them —
which is apparently whatever the current time is when git creates the
(shallow) clone.

This commit is a port of w3c/csswg-drafts#7932.

Co-authored-by: Michael[tm] Smith <mike@w3.org>

issue.title: Elaborate on Exposed=* advice

labels.name: clarification
labels.description: Standard could be clearer

issue.body:
Currently we have this:

> `[Exposed=*]` is to be used with care. It is only appropriate when an API does not expose significant new capabilities. If the API might be restricted or disabled in some environments, it is preferred to list the globals explicitly. 

I think it would help if we listed the principles or criteria that were used to select the initial set of interfaces. Ideally specific enough that it's clear why `ErrorEvent` is included and `MouseEvent` and `reportError()` are excluded. As that would help a lot with carrying this forward consistently into the future.

(Context: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/7591.)

cc @Ms2ger @domenic @smaug---- @leobalter @caridy @mhofman

comment.body:
It seems like so far the set of APIs chosen to be included inside shadow realms has been limited to interfaces (rather than to methods or properties defined in the global property) plus `self` which is defined programmatically in #5339. In particular, there doesn't seem to be any reason to exclude methods like `setTimeout`, `reportError` or even `structuredClone`, other than the fact that `[Exposed=*]` as currently defined doesn't work for them.

I don't think such methods have been considered that much, and maybe this is not the right issue (since as mentioned `[Exposed=*]` wouldn't work with methods), but it is something that should not be left out of consideration just because it would be more difficult to make them work in the specification.

issue.title: Consider not exposing ErrorEvent/PromiseRejectionEvent in ShadowRealms
issue.body:
Exposing PromiseRejectionEvent in Shadow Realms doesn't make much sense, since the global isn't an EventTarget.
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#unhandled-promise-rejections just doesn't work with that kind of globals.
And https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#report-the-exception doesn't really work either, again because the global isn't an EventTarget.

comment.body:
> To avoid this complexity, I would recommend that both uncaught errors and unhandled rejections have a mechanism to be handled directly inside the ShadowRealm. That's why I suggested above a new `globalThis.errors` which would be an event target for these purposes.

HTML has a mechanism where if an error is uncaught inside a dedicated worker, [it will be reported as an error in the worker's "parent"](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/workers.html#runtime-script-errors-2), possibly propagating up the chain until you reach a non-dedicated worker agent (which usually is the window's main agent). The thrown exception is obviously not included in such error events (the `error` attribute of `ErrorEvent` is set to `null`), but if something similar is adopted for ShadowRealms, it could include a copied error with the semantics in https://github.com/tc39/proposal-shadowrealm/blob/main/errors.md.

There doesn't seem to be anything equivalent for unhandled promise rejections, but I wonder if it could be added as well.

pull_request.title: refactor: Have `ArrayBuffer::data` return `Option<NonNull<c_void>>`
pull_request.body:
The pointer returned by `ArrayBuffer::data` might be null if the backing store has zero length, but the return type `*mut c_void` does not force the user to consider this case. This change makes the return type `Option<NonNull<c_void>>`, which is semantically equivalent, but which forces users of the API to handle the `None` case.

This PR is the `ArrayBuffer` counterpart to #817.

This is a breaking API change.

issue.title: Proposal for safe async I/O with `ArrayBuffer`s
Proposal for safe async I/O with `ArrayBuffer`s

comment.body: I just realized that we'd have to figure out how to make this work with the [TC39 resizable buffers proposal](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-resizablearraybuffer), and it might not be trivial. But doing async I/O in repeated non-blocking synchronous steps _can_ work with a resizing buffer, which is much better than borrowing a slice that then might end up covering memory past the end of the `ArrayBuffer` (as it would be in the way Deno does I/O currently).

pull_request.title: experiment(core): Make resource I/O ops take `DetachedBuffer`
pull_request.body:
In Rust, it is UB if a shared slice (of elements without interior mutability) gets mutated while it is borrowed, and it is also UB if a mutable slice gets mutated _or accessed_ while it is borrowed except through the borrow. In async ops in particular, it is unsound to deref (mutably or immutably) a `ZeroCopyBuf` across an `await` point, since there might be references to the `ArrayBuffer` which are accessible to JS, and therefore the slice could be mutated while it is borrowed in our async op.

`Deno.core.{read,write,writeAll}`, which are the backbone of streams and other I/O APIs in Deno, have this issue; and fixing them would greatly reduce the surface for this unsoundness, and would make a first step towards a more in-depth fix of this issue.

The way this PR fixes these APIs is by changing their `ZeroCopyBuf` input parameters to `DetachedBuffer` –which makes the `ArrayBuffer`'s backing store inaccessible from JS– and returning the same `DetachedBuffer` in cases where it is needed.

This API can be used straightforwardly to implement web streams, but there still are `Reader` and `Writer` interfaces in `Deno.Conn`, `Deno.FsFile` and `Deno.std{in,out,err}` which expect a passed buffer to be read or written to asynchronously. In order to make these APIs work with an underlying API based on `DetachedBuffer`, the contents are being copied. Since all of these APIs have a stream-based version, hopefully the old APIs can be deprecated, making this decrease in performance less relevant for the overall experience of Deno users.

comment.body:
> Can you provide any context on performance changes with this PR?

I haven't run any benchmarks yet, but I expect that changing the `read` and `write` methods of those APIs to make a copy would degrade their performance to some extent. I'll try to find any benchmarks that use these methods, or write some if there aren't any, later today.

issue.title: Disallow memory slices as inputs to async ops
issue.body:
In Rust, it is UB if a slice is mutated while borrowed except through the slice itself, and it is also UB if a mutable slice is read while borrowed. The op macro allows borrowing an `ArrayBuffer{,View}` as a memory slice for the duration of an op, but this is not sound for async ops, since the `ArrayBuffer` could be accessed from JS during the await points. This PR therefore disallows such automatic borrowing only for async ops.

pull_request.title: Add `ArrayBuffer::set_detach_key`
pull_request.body: This method, introduced in V8 10.9, makes it so an `ArrayBuffer` object is impossible to detach unless a specific detach key is passed to the `detach` method. Such `ArrayBuffer`s still count as detachable as per the `ArrayBuffer::is_detachable` method, but otherwise behave much like WebAssembly memories.

commits.message:
Ignore environment variables set by cargo (#825)

This avoids constant rebuilds when alternating between running

$ cargo build
$ cargo run <something that runs cargo build>

Since the second command will see these environment variables set
during the logic deciding if build.rs should be rerun or not.

Since these are cargo specific variables, hopefully cargo already does
the right thing without our help.

Rolling to V8 9.7.106.2 (#827)

Co-authored-by: Luca Casonato <hello@lcas.dev>

Make lifetime in `FunctionCallback` signature more restrictive (#822)

This makes the callbacks themselves less restrictive. A test is added
the would fail to compile before.

chore: Specify the rust toolchain version (#821)

Tests in tests/compile_fail/ depend on a specific toolchain version. For
example, they currently fail with 1.58.0-nightly because of extra
warnings.

refactor: Have `BackingStore::data` return `Option<NonNull<c_void>>` (#817)

The pointer returned by `BackingStore::data` might be null if the
backing store has zero length, but the return type `*mut c_void` does
not force the user to consider this case. This change makes the return
type `Option<NonNull<c_void>>`, which is semantically equivalent, but
which forces users of the API to handle the `None` case.

This is a breaking API change.

v8: fix segfault during concurrent isolate creation/disposal on Windows (#829)

This patch includes a test for this issue.

The V8 patch is intentionally left simple to avoid merge conflicts in
the future. To be landed upstream, the `unwindinfo_use_count_` would
probably have to be made non-atomic and we'd have to add a cctest.

Upstream bug: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/v8/issues/detail?id=12393

Fixes: #714

pull_request.title: Update `ArrayBuffer::was_detached` to not use `OpenHandle`
pull_request.body: In #1103, the `ArrayBuffer::was_detached` method was added to rusty_v8 to fill a gap in the C++ API, and it was implemented using the internal `v8::Utils::OpenHandle`. Since then, a `WasDetached` method was added to `ArrayBuffer` in V8 10.9. This PR updates the implementation to use that.

issue.title: Atomics.waitAsync bug

comment.body:
> Wanted to see if I can help find the bug, but I can't even find the place where `Atomics.waitAsync` is implemented.

Deno doesn't implement `Atomics.waitAsync`, that's implemented in V8, the JS engine that Deno (as well as Node.js and Chrome) use. Assuming this is not a V8 bug, it's almost certainly related to Deno's event loop code not knowing about `Atomics.waitAsync` and only knowing about "ops" (Deno's word for Rust functions that are passed into deno_core so they get exposed into the Javascript VM). The relevant code is in [`JsRuntime::poll_event_loop`](https://github.com/denoland/deno/blob/main/core/runtime.rs#LL1019) (or perhaps elsewhere in `JsRuntime`), but I doubt it would be easy to fix.

comment.body:
It used to be the case that passing SABs to Rust didn't work, because `ZeroCopyBuf` explicitly disallowed SABs. #15922 made this possible, and apparently no one noticed.

Accessing SAB data as a `&[u8]` or `&mut [u8]` is unsound because the buffer could be modified at any point by a worker. It has essentially the same safety guarantees as transmuting a `&[AtomicU8]`.

issue.title: Web Compatibility

labels.name: compat-bug-proposal
labels.description: Proposals for web compat bugs

labels.name: focus-area-proposal
labels.description: Focus Area Proposal

issue.body:
### Description

A focus area for small bugs that cause known site compatibility issues, or documented problems for authors creating libraries or sites, but which are not part of a larger feature that's appropriate for its own focus area.

### Rationale

Observed compatibility bugs which cause breakage for users are often not missing features, but specific cases where existing browsers don't follow the spec for features that are implemented. On their own these would be hard to fit into the Interop process since a focus area for a single bug, however important, is hard to weigh as part of the metric. However having a single focus area for these issues seems to have worked well in 2022, with browsers going from ~20% to ~100%, and fixing several bugs that were known to cause problems for users, but had not previously got priority.

### Specification

All included bugs will have a specification (although in some cases it may be that "success" is changing the specification, testcase, and "conforming" implementations to match what's actually required by compat).

Inclusions will be motivated by observed compat issues (e.g. in [webcompat.com](https://webcompat.com) or author-reported issues that they've had to work around when developing libraries.

### Tests

Since this is a somewhat miscellaneous selection of bugs, it's anticipated that tests may be added from other focus areas where the overall focus area doesn't get priority but there are a small number of observed pain points which do get priority. During the selection process participants can request removal of any tests that would cause them to object to the proposal.

Suggested bugs / rationale (tests to be added):

* Remove (or standardise?) overflow: overlay
  * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=55436
  * https://github.com/webcompat/knowledge-base/blob/main/data/overflow-overlay.yml
* Flexbox/abspos paint order
  * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=606208
* Decorating box semantics
  * Webcompat issue: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1584348
  * https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=135353
  * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1008951 (recently fixed)

comment.body:
>    * white-space: break-spaces
>      * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1261435
>      * https://codepen.io/kizu/pen/mdMEOvw can be converted to a reftest with some care

In Igalia we're starting to look into this issue, and we'll probably be fixing it at some point in 2023. The issue should probably be limited to the fact that Chromium counts an element boundary before a space as a line breaking opportunity, and you can reproduce this in a test case that doesn't use zoom. The fact that different zoom levels result in different line breaks even when the line width does not depend on the viewport size is a separate issue that should not count for Interop 2023.

However, as we were initially looking into this bug, we noticed that Webkit does seem to have this bug in some cases, although maybe not in all of the cases where Chromium has it. So should it still count for Interop 2023?

issue.body: Closes: https://github.com/wintercg/proposal-common-minimum-api/issues/17

comment.body: The File API spec hasn't been well maintained for some time, and there are a couple long-standing issues where the spec is known to be broken (such as w3c/FileAPI#43). However, since `FormData` requires `Blob` and `File`, and there's no other way to have files in `multipart/form-data` (short of actually implementing the serialization or parsing manually), I guess adding them would be fine.

issue.title: structuredClone(): fix WPT cases to test transferables with the { transfer: [ list of transferables ] } second parameter
issue.body:
In the `structuredClone` algorithm, the second parameter passed should be
```js
{
  transfer: [ obj1, obj2 ] // list of transferables
}
```
rather than just an array.

This behavior is specified in <https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-structuredclone> and implemented by Chrome, Firefox, and Node.js.

comment.body:
`runner.structuredClone` is a testing API implemented by runners defined elsewhere. For example, `html/webappapis/structured-clone/structured-clone.any.js` takes the second argument of `runner.structuredClone` and passes it as the `transfer` property of the object in the second parameter – whereas `html/infrastructure/safe-passing-of-structured-data/window-postmessage.window.js` simply passes the second argument of `runner.structuredClone` as the second argument of `window.postMessage`, since that is allowed. So this PR is not needed, and it would actually break things unless the runners are updated in turn.

If there is some runner that's using this second argument without mapping it, that should be changed, but probably in a separate PR.

issue.title: The `anchor()` function doesn't support variables as anchor targets
issue.body:
The optional first argument of the `anchor()` function, which is a dashed ident that indicates the anchor target, can be replaced by a custom property: for example, `anchor(var(--anchor) left)`. This variable substitution is not supported in this polyfill.

https://codepen.io/andreubotella/pen/mdKexxX

This polyfill doesn't set any additional styles on the target element, and therefore it shows up below the anchor. Whereas on (canary) Chromium with the `CSSAnchorPosition` feature enabled, it is positioned just right of the "Anchor" text.

Supporting this, together with #44, will allow defining a reusable class for tooltips in a CSS file and allow individual elements to define their anchor names or the anchor to be positioned against using `style` attributes, since this is arguably semantic CSS.

The codepen in the OP currently throws an exception that will be fixed with #47, but even with that fix applied, it still does not apply any `left` or `top` styles to `.target`. comment.body:
> Could you provide some context on `ShadowRealm`? Is there an issue / PR about this?

It's a JS API proposal that's currently being worked on: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-shadowrealm

Unlike most new JS APIs that Deno implements automatically because they ship in V8, this one requires some work to support in the internals of Deno. You can follow the work at denoland/deno#13239 (although the work recently had to be rolled back in denoland/deno#16366 because it was blocking certain refactors; it should hopefully be relanded in a couple weeks).

However, `vm` needs some more support in `deno_core` (and maybe `deno_runtime`) than `ShadowRealm` needs, because you cannot cross objects across the realm boundary with `ShadowRealm` but you can with `vm`. This would need a lot of checking that everything is handled correctly, and that certain realm interactions happen properly, that wouldn't be needed with `ShadowRealm`.

issue.title: Clarify value direction for elements "progress" and "meter" with vertical writing mode

labels.name: i18n-tracker
labels.description: Group bringing to attention of Internationalization, or tracked by i18n but not needing response.

labels.name: i18n-jlreq
labels.description: Notifies Japanese script experts of relevant issues

labels.name: i18n-clreq
labels.description: Notifies Chinese script experts of relevant issues

labels.name: i18n-mlreq
labels.description: Notifies traditional Mongolian script experts of relevant issues

issue.body:
Currently, elements "progress" and "meter" don't have well defined behavior when they have the style `writing-mode: vertical-lr` or `writing-mode: vertical-rl`. For example, Firefox is the only vendor to support vertical writing-mode for these elements. Here is what a progress bar looks like: ```HTML 70% ``` Question 1: Should the value part (blue color) of the element be rendered from top down (as reading is normally done from top to bottom) or should it be rendered bottom to top (so it looks like a glassware that gets filled up)?

Further, currently for the horizontal mode, we are able to change the direction of the progress bar from left-to-right to right-to-left. ```HTML 70% 70% ``` However, there are no direction for ttb `top-to-bottom` or btt `bottom-to-top` (not that I am aware of at least). Question 2: Should there be a way to allow changing direction for the vertical writing modes?


Spec link: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-progress-element https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-meter-element https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes-4/#block-flow https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes/#direction (ps: was told that this question is better fit for whatwg/html instead of csswg https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7929)

comment.body:
> I'm curious to know why you think this is not good practice (especially given that Blink, Gecko, and WebKit browsers all currently apply the RTL directionality for the progress bar). Do you have information from RTL script users indicating a preference for it to be otherwise?

It looked like the OP was about changing the direction of progress/meter bars in absence of any internationalization need for it, just as a styling change. That's what I was objecting to. If that's not what was meant, my bad.

issue.title: Clarify value direction for elements "progress" and "meter" with vertical writing mode
issue.body:
Currently, elements "progress" and "meter" don't have well defined behavior when they have the style `writing-mode: vertical-lr` or `writing-mode: vertical-rl`. For example, Firefox is the only vendor to support vertical writing-mode for these elements. Here is what a progress bar looks like: ```HTML 70% ``` Question 1: Should the value part (blue color) of the element be rendered from top down (as reading is normally done from top to bottom) or should it be rendered bottom to top (so it looks like a glassware that gets filled up)?

Further, currently for the horizontal mode, we are able to change the direction of the progress bar from left-to-right to right-to-left. ```HTML 70% 70% ``` However, there are no direction for ttb `top-to-bottom` or btt `bottom-to-top` (not that I am aware of at least). Question 2: Should there be a way to allow changing direction for the vertical writing modes?


Spec link: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-progress-element https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-meter-element https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes-4/#block-flow https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes/#direction (ps: was told that this question is better fit for whatwg/html instead of csswg https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7929)

comment.body:
The `direction` CSS property isn't meant to change the direction of a progress bar, but to change the direction of the inline progression of text, meant to be used for languages that are written right-to-left such as Hebrew and Arabic. Changing the direction of the progress bar is a side effect. And in cases such as writing rotated RTL languages in vertical text, the `direction` property can still be used ([where "left" maps to top and "right" to bottom](https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-writing-modes/#line-left)).

That said, HTML should indeed probably specify the native (and primitive) apparence of `<progress>` and `<meter>` in terms of [`block-size` and `inline-size`](https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-logical-1/#propdef-block-size), rather than `height` and `width`.

Generate lint categories and explanations with `declare_clippy_lint`

Changes it to be a proc_macro rather than macro_rules

Auto merge of #9541 - Alexendoo:declare-proc-macro, r=flip1995

Generate lint categories and explanations with `declare_clippy_lint`

This means contributors will no longer have to run `cargo dev update_lints` after changing a lints documentation or its category, which may also mean fewer merge conflicts in general

It works by swapping `declare_clippy_lint` out for a `proc_macro` of the same name. The proc macro emits a `LintInfo` alongside the generated `Lint` which are gathered into `declared_lint::LINTS`. The categories/explanations are then read from `declared_lint::LINTS` at runtime

The removal of `src/docs` is split into a separate commit to be more easily ignored

It is slightly slower though, adding a bit under a second to build time. Less noticeable in full builds or with a slower linker (benchmark uses mold)

```bash
hyperfine --warmup 2 \
    --parameter-list commit "declare-proc-macro,master" \
    --command-name "{commit}" \
    --setup "git checkout {commit}" \
    --prepare "touch clippy_lints/src/lib.rs" \
    "cargo build"
```

issue.title: "Abort a running script" doesn't abort function invocations

comment.body:
> Right now [ECMA-262 doesn’t really allow for this to occur](https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/issues/401). Like, it’s not just missing from ES, it’s “impossible” as a consequence of ES’s own semantics I think(?) This seems to be why the section opens with “Although the JavaScript specification does not account for this possibility.” There are more related issues linked to from that one which color in the picture more.
> 
> The changes needed are nuts and bolts things squarely inside the ES “jurisdiction,” e.g. it’d touch the real scary stuff (well, to me I mean) related to memory model invariants I suspect & till ES’s own semantics permit termination to occur, it seems short & sweet on the HTML side is probably a safer stopgap than attempted precision that’s known to be wrong underneath.

True, but the UA-level (rather than JS engine-level) semantics, in terms of what happens when script execution is aborted during a callback invocation, are not defined at all, and this would indeed fall on the HTML / WebIDL side to define. I suppose this can't be done fully until TC39 specifies aborting scripts, but some progress in defining the semantics could still be made before that.

Merge pull request #7800 from vmpstr/update-set-intro

This patch does a few things:
1. Fixes a small handful of whitespace / typo problems
2. Adds an example showing how the font-weight descriptor can accept a range
3. Advises authors to use high-level font-variant properties instead of font-feature-settings
4. Rewrites an example to follow the above advice

As per suggestion in https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8348.
[css-grid-1][css-grid-2] Slight editorial tweak to make the 'grid' options clearer.
[css-grid-1][css-grid-2] Clarify that <'grid-template'> serialization is preferred if 'grid' is ambiguous. #7805
[css-grid-2] Generate separate hypoth items for each edge, so assymmetric mbp is handled correctly. #7465
[css-grid-1][css-grid-2][editorial] Clarify that tracks can't be *fully* intrinsic, but can have an intrinsic length (if paired with a fixed in minmax()). #7238

Removed mentioning of orphans and widows

The `orphans` and `widows` properties were moved to CSS Fragmentation 3. Therefore they got removed.
[css-color-4] Missing in rgb serializes as 0,  fix #6959
Specify that highlight repaints must be async (#6987)

[css-pseudo] text decorations on highlight pseudos (closes #6022) (#6666)

Clarify highlight decoration semantics

[css-2022] Set up 2022 snapshot

Includes 'hyphenate-character' as a shippable property, as per #6887
Fix to create symlinks inside the /test folder

Generate timestamps.json file w/ git timestamps for sources

For the GH Pages deployment, this change generates a timestamps.json file
that maps each shortname in the repo to a timestamp representing the time
for the most recent commit of corresponding Bikeshed source file for that
shortname — enabling any downstream users/consumers of the deployed
GH Pages specs to have accurate last-committed data for all sources.

This commit is a port of w3c/csswg-drafts#7898.

Co-authored-by: Michael[tm] Smith <mike@w3.org>

Do full clone rather than shallow clone

This change causes the GH Pages build to do a full clone rather than a
shallow clone. This is necessary in order to get the correct timestamps
for all sources (see 8a88ad6).

Otherwise, without this change, git doesn’t report accurate timestamps
for any sources; instead it reports the same timestamp for all of them —
which is apparently whatever the current time is when git creates the
(shallow) clone.

This commit is a port of w3c/csswg-drafts#7932.

Co-authored-by: Michael[tm] Smith <mike@w3.org>

issue.title: Elaborate on Exposed=* advice

labels.name: clarification
labels.description: Standard could be clearer

issue.body:
Currently we have this:

> `[Exposed=*]` is to be used with care. It is only appropriate when an API does not expose significant new capabilities. If the API might be restricted or disabled in some environments, it is preferred to list the globals explicitly. 

I think it would help if we listed the principles or criteria that were used to select the initial set of interfaces. Ideally specific enough that it's clear why `ErrorEvent` is included and `MouseEvent` and `reportError()` are excluded. As that would help a lot with carrying this forward consistently into the future.

(Context: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/7591.)

cc @Ms2ger @domenic @smaug---- @leobalter @caridy @mhofman

comment.body:
It seems like so far the set of APIs chosen to be included inside shadow realms has been limited to interfaces (rather than to methods or properties defined in the global property) plus `self` which is defined programmatically in #5339. In particular, there doesn't seem to be any reason to exclude methods like `setTimeout`, `reportError` or even `structuredClone`, other than the fact that `[Exposed=*]` as currently defined doesn't work for them.

I don't think such methods have been considered that much, and maybe this is not the right issue (since as mentioned `[Exposed=*]` wouldn't work with methods), but it is something that should not be left out of consideration just because it would be more difficult to make them work in the specification.

issue.title: Consider not exposing ErrorEvent/PromiseRejectionEvent in ShadowRealms
issue.body:
Exposing PromiseRejectionEvent in Shadow Realms doesn't make much sense, since the global isn't an EventTarget.
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#unhandled-promise-rejections just doesn't work with that kind of globals.
And https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#report-the-exception doesn't really work either, again because the global isn't an EventTarget.

comment.body:
> To avoid this complexity, I would recommend that both uncaught errors and unhandled rejections have a mechanism to be handled directly inside the ShadowRealm. That's why I suggested above a new `globalThis.errors` which would be an event target for these purposes.

HTML has a mechanism where if an error is uncaught inside a dedicated worker, [it will be reported as an error in the worker's "parent"](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/workers.html#runtime-script-errors-2), possibly propagating up the chain until you reach a non-dedicated worker agent (which usually is the window's main agent). The thrown exception is obviously not included in such error events (the `error` attribute of `ErrorEvent` is set to `null`), but if something similar is adopted for ShadowRealms, it could include a copied error with the semantics in https://github.com/tc39/proposal-shadowrealm/blob/main/errors.md.

There doesn't seem to be anything equivalent for unhandled promise rejections, but I wonder if it could be added as well.

pull_request.title: refactor: Have `ArrayBuffer::data` return `Option<NonNull<c_void>>`
pull_request.body:
The pointer returned by `ArrayBuffer::data` might be null if the backing store has zero length, but the return type `*mut c_void` does not force the user to consider this case. This change makes the return type `Option<NonNull<c_void>>`, which is semantically equivalent, but which forces users of the API to handle the `None` case.

This PR is the `ArrayBuffer` counterpart to #817.

This is a breaking API change.

issue.title: Proposal for safe async I/O with `ArrayBuffer`s
Proposal for safe async I/O with `ArrayBuffer`s

comment.body: I just realized that we'd have to figure out how to make this work with the [TC39 resizable buffers proposal](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-resizablearraybuffer), and it might not be trivial. But doing async I/O in repeated non-blocking synchronous steps _can_ work with a resizing buffer, which is much better than borrowing a slice that then might end up covering memory past the end of the `ArrayBuffer` (as it would be in the way Deno does I/O currently).

pull_request.title: experiment(core): Make resource I/O ops take `DetachedBuffer`
pull_request.body:
In Rust, it is UB if a shared slice (of elements without interior mutability) gets mutated while it is borrowed, and it is also UB if a mutable slice gets mutated _or accessed_ while it is borrowed except through the borrow. In async ops in particular, it is unsound to deref (mutably or immutably) a `ZeroCopyBuf` across an `await` point, since there might be references to the `ArrayBuffer` which are accessible to JS, and therefore the slice could be mutated while it is borrowed in our async op.

`Deno.core.{read,write,writeAll}`, which are the backbone of streams and other I/O APIs in Deno, have this issue; and fixing them would greatly reduce the surface for this unsoundness, and would make a first step towards a more in-depth fix of this issue.

The way this PR fixes these APIs is by changing their `ZeroCopyBuf` input parameters to `DetachedBuffer` –which makes the `ArrayBuffer`'s backing store inaccessible from JS– and returning the same `DetachedBuffer` in cases where it is needed.

This API can be used straightforwardly to implement web streams, but there still are `Reader` and `Writer` interfaces in `Deno.Conn`, `Deno.FsFile` and `Deno.std{in,out,err}` which expect a passed buffer to be read or written to asynchronously. In order to make these APIs work with an underlying API based on `DetachedBuffer`, the contents are being copied. Since all of these APIs have a stream-based version, hopefully the old APIs can be deprecated, making this decrease in performance less relevant for the overall experience of Deno users.

comment.body:
> Can you provide any context on performance changes with this PR?

I haven't run any benchmarks yet, but I expect that changing the `read` and `write` methods of those APIs to make a copy would degrade their performance to some extent. I'll try to find any benchmarks that use these methods, or write some if there aren't any, later today.

issue.title: Disallow memory slices as inputs to async ops
issue.body:
In Rust, it is UB if a slice is mutated while borrowed except through the slice itself, and it is also UB if a mutable slice is read while borrowed. The op macro allows borrowing an `ArrayBuffer{,View}` as a memory slice for the duration of an op, but this is not sound for async ops, since the `ArrayBuffer` could be accessed from JS during the await points. This PR therefore disallows such automatic borrowing only for async ops.

Ignore environment variables set by cargo (#825)

This avoids constant rebuilds when alternating between running

$ cargo build
$ cargo run <something that runs cargo build>

Since the second command will see these environment variables set
during the logic deciding if build.rs should be rerun or not.

Since these are cargo specific variables, hopefully cargo already does
the right thing without our help.

refactor: Have `BackingStore::data` return `Option<NonNull<c_void>>` (#817)

The pointer returned by `BackingStore::data` might be null if the
backing store has zero length, but the return type `*mut c_void` does
not force the user to consider this case. This change makes the return
type `Option<NonNull<c_void>>`, which is semantically equivalent, but
which forces users of the API to handle the `None` case.

This is a breaking API change.

v8: fix segfault during concurrent isolate creation/disposal on Windows (#829)

This patch includes a test for this issue.

The V8 patch is intentionally left simple to avoid merge conflicts in
the future. To be landed upstream, the `unwindinfo_use_count_` would
probably have to be made non-atomic and we'd have to add a cctest.

Upstream bug: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/v8/issues/detail?id=12393

Fixes: #714

pull_request.body: In #1103, the `ArrayBuffer::was_detached` method was added to rusty_v8 to fill a gap in the C++ API, and it was implemented using the internal `v8::Utils::OpenHandle`. Since then, a `WasDetached` method was added to `ArrayBuffer` in V8 10.9. This PR updates the implementation to use that.

issue.title: Atomics.waitAsync bug

comment.body:
> Wanted to see if I can help find the bug, but I can't even find the place where `Atomics.waitAsync` is implemented.

Deno doesn't implement `Atomics.waitAsync`, that's implemented in V8, the JS engine that Deno (as well as Node.js and Chrome) use. Assuming this is not a V8 bug, it's almost certainly related to Deno's event loop code not knowing about `Atomics.waitAsync` and only knowing about "ops" (Deno's word for Rust functions that are passed into deno_core so they get exposed into the Javascript VM). The relevant code is in [`JsRuntime::poll_event_loop`](https://github.com/denoland/deno/blob/main/core/runtime.rs#LL1019) (or perhaps elsewhere in `JsRuntime`), but I doubt it would be easy to fix.

comment.body:
It used to be the case that passing SABs to Rust didn't work, because `ZeroCopyBuf` explicitly disallowed SABs. #15922 made this possible, and apparently no one noticed.

Accessing SAB data as a `&[u8]` or `&mut [u8]` is unsound because the buffer could be modified at any point by a worker. It has essentially the same safety guarantees as transmuting a `&[AtomicU8]`.

issue.title: Web Compatibility

labels.name: compat-bug-proposal
labels.description: Proposals for web compat bugs

labels.name: focus-area-proposal
labels.description: Focus Area Proposal

issue.body:
### Description

A focus area for small bugs that cause known site compatibility issues, or documented problems for authors creating libraries or sites, but which are not part of a larger feature that's appropriate for its own focus area.

### Rationale

Observed compatibility bugs which cause breakage for users are often not missing features, but specific cases where existing browsers don't follow the spec for features that are implemented. On their own these would be hard to fit into the Interop process since a focus area for a single bug, however important, is hard to weigh as part of the metric. However having a single focus area for these issues seems to have worked well in 2022, with browsers going from ~20% to ~100%, and fixing several bugs that were known to cause problems for users, but had not previously got priority.

### Specification

All included bugs will have a specification (although in some cases it may be that "success" is changing the specification, testcase, and "conforming" implementations to match what's actually required by compat).

Inclusions will be motivated by observed compat issues (e.g. in [webcompat.com](https://webcompat.com) or author-reported issues that they've had to work around when developing libraries.

### Tests

Since this is a somewhat miscellaneous selection of bugs, it's anticipated that tests may be added from other focus areas where the overall focus area doesn't get priority but there are a small number of observed pain points which do get priority. During the selection process participants can request removal of any tests that would cause them to object to the proposal.

Suggested bugs / rationale (tests to be added):

* Remove (or standardise?) overflow: overlay
  * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=55436
  * https://github.com/webcompat/knowledge-base/blob/main/data/overflow-overlay.yml
* Flexbox/abspos paint order
  * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=606208
* Decorating box semantics
  * Webcompat issue: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1584348
  * https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=135353
  * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1008951 (recently fixed)

comment.body:
>    * white-space: break-spaces
>      * https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1261435
>      * https://codepen.io/kizu/pen/mdMEOvw can be converted to a reftest with some care

In Igalia we're starting to look into this issue, and we'll probably be fixing it at some point in 2023. The issue should probably be limited to the fact that Chromium counts an element boundary before a space as a line breaking opportunity, and you can reproduce this in a test case that doesn't use zoom. The fact that different zoom levels result in different line breaks even when the line width does not depend on the viewport size is a separate issue that should not count for Interop 2023.

However, as we were initially looking into this bug, we noticed that Webkit does seem to have this bug in some cases, although maybe not in all of the cases where Chromium has it. So should it still count for Interop 2023?

issue.title: Add Blob and File
issue.body: Closes: https://github.com/wintercg/proposal-common-minimum-api/issues/17

comment.body: The File API spec hasn't been well maintained for some time, and there are a couple long-standing issues where the spec is known to be broken (such as w3c/FileAPI#43). However, since `FormData` requires `Blob` and `File`, and there's no other way to have files in `multipart/form-data` (short of actually implementing the serialization or parsing manually), I guess adding them would be fine.

issue.title: structuredClone(): fix WPT cases to test transferables with the { transfer: [ list of transferables ] } second parameter
issue.body:
In the `structuredClone` algorithm, the second parameter passed should be
```js
{
  transfer: [ obj1, obj2 ] // list of transferables
}
```
rather than just an array.

This behavior is specified in <https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-structuredclone> and implemented by Chrome, Firefox, and Node.js.

comment.body:
`runner.structuredClone` is a testing API implemented by runners defined elsewhere. For example, `html/webappapis/structured-clone/structured-clone.any.js` takes the second argument of `runner.structuredClone` and passes it as the `transfer` property of the object in the second parameter – whereas `html/infrastructure/safe-passing-of-structured-data/window-postmessage.window.js` simply passes the second argument of `runner.structuredClone` as the second argument of `window.postMessage`, since that is allowed. So this PR is not needed, and it would actually break things unless the runners are updated in turn.

If there is some runner that's using this second argument without mapping it, that should be changed, but probably in a separate PR.

issue.title: The `anchor()` function doesn't support variables as anchor targets
issue.body:
The optional first argument of the `anchor()` function, which is a dashed ident that indicates the anchor target, can be replaced by a custom property: for example, `anchor(var(--anchor) left)`. This variable substitution is not supported in this polyfill.

https://codepen.io/andreubotella/pen/mdKexxX

This polyfill doesn't set any additional styles on the target element, and therefore it shows up below the anchor. Whereas on (canary) Chromium with the `CSSAnchorPosition` feature enabled, it is positioned just right of the "Anchor" text.

Supporting this, together with #44, will allow defining a reusable class for tooltips in a CSS file and allow individual elements to define their anchor names or the anchor to be positioned against using `style` attributes, since this is arguably semantic CSS.

comment.body:
> Could you provide some context on `ShadowRealm`? Is there an issue / PR about this?

It's a JS API proposal that's currently being worked on: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-shadowrealm

Unlike most new JS APIs that Deno implements automatically because they ship in V8, this one requires some work to support in the internals of Deno. You can follow the work at denoland/deno#13239 (although the work recently had to be rolled back in denoland/deno#16366 because it was blocking certain refactors; it should hopefully be relanded in a couple weeks).

However, `vm` needs some more support in `deno_core` (and maybe `deno_runtime`) than `ShadowRealm` needs, because you cannot cross objects across the realm boundary with `ShadowRealm` but you can with `vm`. This would need a lot of checking that everything is handled correctly, and that certain realm interactions happen properly, that wouldn't be needed with `ShadowRealm`.

issue.title: Clarify value direction for elements "progress" and "meter" with vertical writing mode

labels.name: i18n-tracker
labels.description: Group bringing to attention of Internationalization, or tracked by i18n but not needing response.

labels.name: i18n-jlreq
labels.description: Notifies Japanese script experts of relevant issues

labels.name: i18n-clreq
labels.description: Notifies Chinese script experts of relevant issues

labels.name: i18n-mlreq
labels.description: Notifies traditional Mongolian script experts of relevant issues

issue.body:
Currently, elements "progress" and "meter" don't have well defined behavior when they have the style `writing-mode: vertical-lr` or `writing-mode: vertical-rl`. For example, Firefox is the only vendor to support vertical writing-mode for these elements. Here is what a progress bar looks like: ```HTML 70% ``` Question 1: Should the value part (blue color) of the element be rendered from top down (as reading is normally done from top to bottom) or should it be rendered bottom to top (so it looks like a glassware that gets filled up)?

Further, currently for the horizontal mode, we are able to change the direction of the progress bar from left-to-right to right-to-left. ```HTML 70% 70% ``` However, there are no direction for ttb `top-to-bottom` or btt `bottom-to-top` (not that I am aware of at least). Question 2: Should there be a way to allow changing direction for the vertical writing modes?


Spec link: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-progress-element https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-meter-element https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes-4/#block-flow https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes/#direction (ps: was told that this question is better fit for whatwg/html instead of csswg https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7929)

comment.body:
> I'm curious to know why you think this is not good practice (especially given that Blink, Gecko, and WebKit browsers all currently apply the RTL directionality for the progress bar). Do you have information from RTL script users indicating a preference for it to be otherwise?

It looked like the OP was about changing the direction of progress/meter bars in absence of any internationalization need for it, just as a styling change. That's what I was objecting to. If that's not what was meant, my bad.

issue.title: Clarify value direction for elements "progress" and "meter" with vertical writing mode
issue.body:
Currently, elements "progress" and "meter" don't have well defined behavior when they have the style `writing-mode: vertical-lr` or `writing-mode: vertical-rl`. For example, Firefox is the only vendor to support vertical writing-mode for these elements. Here is what a progress bar looks like: ```HTML 70% ``` Question 1: Should the value part (blue color) of the element be rendered from top down (as reading is normally done from top to bottom) or should it be rendered bottom to top (so it looks like a glassware that gets filled up)?

Further, currently for the horizontal mode, we are able to change the direction of the progress bar from left-to-right to right-to-left. ```HTML 70% 70% ``` However, there are no direction for ttb `top-to-bottom` or btt `bottom-to-top` (not that I am aware of at least). Question 2: Should there be a way to allow changing direction for the vertical writing modes?


Spec link: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-progress-element https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-meter-element https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes-4/#block-flow https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes/#direction (ps: was told that this question is better fit for whatwg/html instead of csswg https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7929)

comment.body:
The `direction` CSS property isn't meant to change the direction of a progress bar, but to change the direction of the inline progression of text, meant to be used for languages that are written right-to-left such as Hebrew and Arabic. Changing the direction of the progress bar is a side effect. And in cases such as writing rotated RTL languages in vertical text, the `direction` property can still be used ([where "left" maps to top and "right" to bottom](https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-writing-modes/#line-left)).

That said, HTML should indeed probably specify the native (and primitive) apparence of `<progress>` and `<meter>` in terms of [`block-size` and `inline-size`](https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-logical-1/#propdef-block-size), rather than `height` and `width`.

commits.message:
Update `from_raw_with_void_ptr` to support types other than `Box`

This PR updates the `from_raw_with_void_ptr` lint, which covered
`Box::from_raw`, to also cover the `from_raw` static method of the
`Rc`, `Arc`, `alloc::rc::Weak` and `alloc::sync::Weak` types.

It also improves the description and error messages of this lint.

---

changelog: [`from_raw_with_void_ptr`]: Now works with the `Rc`, `Arc`, `alloc::rc::Weak` and `alloc::sync::Weak` types.

Generate lint categories and explanations with `declare_clippy_lint`

Changes it to be a proc_macro rather than macro_rules

Auto merge of #9541 - Alexendoo:declare-proc-macro, r=flip1995

Generate lint categories and explanations with `declare_clippy_lint`

This means contributors will no longer have to run `cargo dev update_lints` after changing a lints documentation or its category, which may also mean fewer merge conflicts in general

It works by swapping `declare_clippy_lint` out for a `proc_macro` of the same name. The proc macro emits a `LintInfo` alongside the generated `Lint` which are gathered into `declared_lint::LINTS`. The categories/explanations are then read from `declared_lint::LINTS` at runtime

The removal of `src/docs` is split into a separate commit to be more easily ignored

It is slightly slower though, adding a bit under a second to build time. Less noticeable in full builds or with a slower linker (benchmark uses mold)

```bash
hyperfine --warmup 2 \
    --parameter-list commit "declare-proc-macro,master" \
    --command-name "{commit}" \
    --setup "git checkout {commit}" \
    --prepare "touch clippy_lints/src/lib.rs" \
    "cargo build"
```
```
Benchmark 1: declare-proc-macro
  Time (mean ± σ):     10.731 s ±  0.154 s    [User: 7.739 s, System: 1.791 s]
  Range (min … max):   10.598 s … 11.125 s    10 runs

Benchmark 2: master
  Time (mean ± σ):      9.422 s ±  0.094 s    [User: 7.183 s, System: 1.732 s]
  Range (min … max):    9.287 s …  9.624 s    10 runs

Summary
  'master' ran
    1.14 ± 0.02 times faster than 'declare-proc-macro'
```

r? `@flip1995`
cc `@llogiq` for `--explain`
